docs.snippet: Those who know Andrew S. Fastow, the man at the center of the Enron scandal, say they often got the sense that he had something to prove.    He was the boy at New Providence High School in New Jersey who always seemed to be running for something; ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Those who know Andrew S. Fastow, the man at the center of the Enron scandal, say they often got the sense that he had something to prove. He was the boy at New Providence High School in New Jersey who always seemed to be running for something; he successfully lobbied to be named the first high school student to sit on the state's board of education. At Tufts University, he pressed college administrators to create a major in Chinese studies so he could put something unique on his résumé.
docs.abstract: Profile of Enron Corp's former chief financial officer, Andrew S Fastow, who has been indicted on federal charges, including fraud, money laundering and conspiracy, in Enron collapse; focuses on Fastow's fast-track rise at Enron; photos (M)

headline.main: From Enron Fast Track To Total Derailment

docs.snippet: Six months after the collapse of Enron, a wave of enthusiasm for overhauling the nation's corporate and accounting laws has ebbed and the toughest proposals for change are all but dead.    A powerful group of lobbyists, playing on partisan disagre...
docs.lead_paragraph: Six months after the collapse of Enron, a wave of enthusiasm for overhauling the nation's corporate and accounting laws has ebbed and the toughest proposals for change are all but dead. A powerful group of lobbyists, playing on partisan disagreement in Congress, appears to have killed efforts to impose tight new controls on corporate conduct. And while some Democrats hope to turn the inaction to their advantage in the fall elections, other lawmakers say that -- barring more business meltdowns that deepen the stock market's two-year slump -- voters are unlikely to care enough to influence their ballots.
docs.abstract: Wave of enthusiasm for overhauling nation's corporate and accounting laws ebbs and toughest proposals for change are all but dead six months after collapse of Enron Corp; powerful group of lobbyists, playing on partisan disagreement in Congress, appears to have killed efforts at reform with bills to impose tight new controls on corporate conduct falling victim to political gridlock; some Democrats hope to turn inaction to advantge in fall elections, but other lawmakers say voters are unlikely to care enough to influence their ballots; Democrats predict sufficient votes to get broad measure of their own out of Banking Committee on party-line vote, but only by tempering it to win support of moderates; main differences between pending legislation favored by House Republicans and Senate Democrats discussed (M)

headline.main: Enthusiasm Waning in Congress For Tougher Post-Enron Controls

byline.original: By STEPHEN LABATON and RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr

docs.snippet: An article on April 30 about a survey sent by the White House to top administration officials, seeking information on their contacts with the Enron Corporation, misspelled the surname of a spokesman who said the administration would cooperate with...
docs.lead_paragraph: An article on April 30 about a survey sent by the White House to top administration officials, seeking information on their contacts with the Enron Corporation, misspelled the surname of a spokesman who said the administration would cooperate with reasonable requests from Congress for information. He is Scott McClellan, not McLellan.
docs.abstract: Correction of Apr 30 article on survey sent by White House to top administration officials, seeking information on their contacts with Enron Corp, regarding spelling of name of spokesman

docs.snippet: ENRON has collapsed, and other energy trading companies have had their wings -- and their stock prices -- clipped. But the battle-tested technicians in Folsom, Calif., who control the nation's largest power grid are acutely aware that energy marke...
docs.lead_paragraph: ENRON has collapsed, and other energy trading companies have had their wings -- and their stock prices -- clipped. But the battle-tested technicians in Folsom, Calif., who control the nation's largest power grid are acutely aware that energy markets remain susceptible to manipulation at the hands of traders doing what traders do -- exploiting loopholes and inefficiencies to maximum gain. ''They will keep testing us any way they can, in big ways and small,'' said Anjali Sheffrin, director of market analysis for the Independent System Operator, the agency that runs California's electricity grid from a control room in Folsom, a town 20 miles from Sacramento that is better known for its prison. ''Unless we are more diligent, we could have the same kind of crisis all over again.''
docs.abstract: Regulators in states where energy companies sell electricity in open market say they are much better at detecting market manipulation of the kind Enron practiced in California during its energy crisis last summer, but they also complain that they still lack tools to properly manage competitive power markets that have gradually supplanted tight regulation and local utility monopolies over last few years; many say Enron's aggressive trading tactics were probably legal under existing rules and that similar schemes remain in wide use because energy markets remain flawed; defenders of deregulation experiment urge patience, saying creating new competitive markets is long-term endeavor; photos; graphs (L)

byline.original: This article was reported by Neela Banerjee, David Barboza, Richard A. Oppel Jr. and Joseph Kahn and was written by Mr. Kahn

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Re ''Enron's Last Charity Ball,'' by Polly Morrice (Op-Ed, March 5):...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Enron's Last Charity Ball,'' by Polly Morrice (Op-Ed, March 5):
docs.abstract: Doug Giebel letter on Mar 5 Op-Ed article comments on Enron's deceptively generous program of giving to Houston causes

docs.snippet: The White House declared its support today for the secretary of the Army, Thomas E. White, after the disclosure that Mr. White had retained a significant interest in Enron from his days as a senior executive there until early this year.    The dis...
docs.lead_paragraph: The White House declared its support today for the secretary of the Army, Thomas E. White, after the disclosure that Mr. White had retained a significant interest in Enron from his days as a senior executive there until early this year. The disclosure that Mr. White had retained options to buy 665,000 Enron shares until January brought sharp criticism from leaders in both parties on the Senate Armed Services Committee. Several said that Mr. White had violated terms of an ethics agreement he signed before becoming the Army secretary. When he took the top Army job, Mr. White pledged to divest himself of any stake in Enron.
docs.abstract: Bush administration declares its support for Army Sec Thomas E White after disclosure that White had retained significant interest in Enron Corp from his days as senior executive there until early 2002; disclosure that White retained options to buy 665,000 Enron shares until January brought sharp criticism from leaders in both political parties on Senate Armed Services Committee; photo (M)

headline.main: White House Supports Official Who Kept Stock Options Till This Year
headline.kicker: ENRON'S MANY STRANDS: THE ARMY SECRETARY

docs.snippet: The Congressional gantlet may not be over for Jeffrey K. Skilling.    A House committee sent a letter today to Mr. Skilling, the former Enron chief executive, saying that recent interviews with other Enron officials ''appear to raise serious quest...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Congressional gantlet may not be over for Jeffrey K. Skilling. A House committee sent a letter today to Mr. Skilling, the former Enron chief executive, saying that recent interviews with other Enron officials ''appear to raise serious questions'' about whether Mr. Skilling told the truth before Congress last month.
docs.abstract: House Energy and Commerce Committee sends letter to former Enron Corp chief executive Jeffrey K Skilling, saying that recent interviews with other Enron officials 'appear to raise serious questions' about whether Skilling told truth before Congress last month; January interviews with three Enron accounting executives concern how much Skilling knew about and approved of restructuring of four partnerships known as Raptors year ago that essentially allowed Enron to delay disclosure of hundreds of millions of dollars in losses; photo (M)

headline.main: House Panel Voices Doubts On Skilling

byline.original: By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. and KURT EICHENWALD

docs.snippet: Now that Congressional investigators have looked at the role of accountants and insiders in the Enron debacle, they are widening their investigation and focusing on Wall Street and the role it played in the company's rise and collapse.    Democrat...
docs.lead_paragraph: Now that Congressional investigators have looked at the role of accountants and insiders in the Enron debacle, they are widening their investigation and focusing on Wall Street and the role it played in the company's rise and collapse. Democratic Senate leaders have put Wall Street's relationship with Enron and potential financial conflicts of interest at the top of a broad Enron-related legislative agenda that was announced last week. Meanwhile, the House committee leading the Enron investigation is gathering documents and preparing to summon Wall Street executives.
docs.abstract: Congressional investigators probing bankruptcy of Enron Corp widen investigation, focusing on Wall Street and role it played in company's rise and fall; Democratic Senate leaders have put Wall Street's relationship with company and potential financial conflicts of interest at top of broad Enron-related legialtive agenda, while House committee leading probe gathers documents and prepares to summon corporate executives; inquiries, still in early stages, will examine way Wall Street firms structured and sold Enron's limited partnerships; will look into reasons why firms were issuing recommendations to buy Enron stock when they had detailed information about company's poor financial condition; photo (M)

headline.main: Congress's Scrutiny Shifts to Wall Street And Its Enron Role

docs.snippet: Lawmakers said today that the Enron Corporation had agreed to waive tax-privacy protections and provide tax records for the last 17 years to the Senate Finance Committee, which has begun an investigation into whether the company improperly avoided...
docs.lead_paragraph: Lawmakers said today that the Enron Corporation had agreed to waive tax-privacy protections and provide tax records for the last 17 years to the Senate Finance Committee, which has begun an investigation into whether the company improperly avoided paying taxes or exploited tax law loopholes. The company has also agreed to provide tax records for its affiliated companies and partnerships.
docs.abstract: Enron Corp agrees to waive tax-privacy protections and provide tax records for last 17 years to Senate Finance Committee, which is investigating whether it improperly avoided paying taxes or exploited tax law loopholes and whether tax laws should be changed; also agrees to provide tax records for its affilated companies and partnerships; photo (M)

headline.main: Enron to Provide 17 Years of Tax Records to Senate Panel

docs.snippet: In the weeks before it filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, Enron allowed a small group of executives to withdraw their money from a deferred compensation program, giving them preferential treatment over some former managers who had also re...
docs.lead_paragraph: In the weeks before it filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, Enron allowed a small group of executives to withdraw their money from a deferred compensation program, giving them preferential treatment over some former managers who had also requested early withdrawal, according to former and current executives at the company. The company paid millions of dollars in deferred salaries and bonuses to midlevel and high-level executives still working in late November, just before the Dec. 2 bankruptcy filing, which forced the company to suspend all such payments. But a number of employees who had retired or recently left the company were denied similar payments.
docs.abstract: Former and current Enron Corp executives say in weeks before company filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, it allowed small group of executives to withdraw their money from deferred compensation program, giving them preferential treatment over some former managers who had also requested early withdrawal; Enron paid millions of dollars in deferred salaries and bonuses to midlevel and high-level executives still working in late November, just before Dec 2 bankruptcy filing, which forced company to suspend payments; number of employees who had retired or recently left company were denied similar payments; some former Enron employees are considering lawsuit in hopes of recovering millions of dollars in deferred compensation they say they are owed; among those unable to withdraw money in November was Charles B Bowman, former senior vice president at Enron Facilities Services; Bowman, who took early retirement in October 2000, says he lost about $750,000 in deferred compensation plan; photos (M)

headline.main: Enron Paid Some, Not All, Deferred Compensation
